Award.AwardTitle: 2018 Geobiology Gordon Research Conference: The microbial planet from deep time to today
Award.AbstractNarration:
This is a request to support the participation of graduate students and postdoctoral fellows from U.S. institutions in the 2018 Geobiology Gordon Research Conference (GRC) that will bring together scientists from across the globe to Galveston, TX between January 21 and 26, 2018. The field of geobiology investigates the coevolution of life and the environment over Earth history, including studies of life and the environment today. Over the past decade, the field of geobiology has produced a strong cohort of scientists who require a meeting of their own to exchange ideas, tools, and expertise. The Graduate Research Seminar (GRS), a two-day meeting for graduate students and postdoctoral scholars, will immediately precede the GRC and give early career scientists an opportunity to organize and participate in focused meetings. GRC and GRS actively promote diversity, eschew review talks and instead demand researchers to share the latest and greatest ideas and questions during the poster and discussion sessions. Because the attendances of GRC and GRS, respectively, are limited to 200 and 60 people, respectively, these meetings will stimulate thoughtful and engaging discussions and spontaneous interactions as well as offering numerous networking opportunities for junior people. By supporting the attendance of GRS and GRC by graduate students and postdoctoral scholars from the U.S., the requested funding will strengthen the sense of community, train junior scientists, promote collaboration and diversity in the field.

Geobiology uses the tools of paleontology, geology, geochemistry and microbiology, but is separated from these more traditional disciplines by an interest in the complex relationships and feedbacks among biological, chemical, and physical processes. The scientific programs for Geobiology GRC and GRS 2018 will investigate interactions among biological, chemical and physical processes on Earth?s surface in daily poster sessions and nine oral sessions, each with two or three invited speakers and a discussion leader. These sessions will highlight open questions, novel experimental and conceptual approaches and active areas of research within the field. Both meetings will encourage open and honest intellectual debate and ask each session chair to encourage rigorous analysis of all science presented or discussed in a manner respectful to all conferees. An informal afternoon meeting titled ?Transition Time: How to find the right career after graduate school or your postdoctoral fellowship? will provide mentoring and support the professional growth of graduate students and postdocs. GRC and the preceding GRS will offer numerous opportunities to socialize and network. These interactions will advance discovery, disseminate results, and train attendees in methods, approaches and presentation skills.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The field of geobiology investigates the coevolution of life and the environment over Earth history, including studies of life and the environment today. Over the past decade, the field of geobiology has produced a strong cohort of scientists who require a meeting of their own to exchange ideas, tools, and expertise. The 2018 Geobiology Gordon Research Conference (GRC) brought together scientists from across the globe to Galveston, TX between January 21 and 26, 2018. The Graduate Research Seminar (GRS), a two-day meeting for graduate students and postdoctoral scholars, immediately preceded the GRC and gave 59 early career scientists an opportunity to organize and participate in focused meetings. The attendees of the GRC represented a diverse mix of about 140 senior and early career researchers.

GRC and GRS actively promoted diversity, eschewed review talks and encouraged the sharing of the latest and greatest ideas and questions during the poster and discussion sessions. The attendances of GRC and GRS, respectively, were limited to 200 and 60 people, respectively, so both meetings stimulated thoughtful and engaging discussions and spontaneous interactions and offered numerous networking opportunities for junior people. By supporting the attendance of GRS and GRC by graduate students and postdoctoral scholars from the U.S., the requested funding strengthened the sense of community, trained junior scientists in presenting, and promoted collaboration and diversity in the field.

The program and attendees of GRC 2018 covered diverse fields and reflected the gender diversity and the international makeup of the community in geobiology. The chair and the co-chair of the GRC were both women, as are more than half (18/31) of the invited speakers and discussion leaders. The vice chair led a GRC Power Hour, an optional informal gathering open to all meeting participants and designed specifically to help address the challenges women face in science. The topic of this years’ Power Hour was “Transition Time: How to find the right career after graduate school or your postdoctoral fellowship”.

The funding for GRS and GRC helped alleviate the registration costs for graduate students and postdoctoral scholars from U.S. institutions. The conference chair notified those awardees whose attendance was supported by the NSF funds. A slide communicating the sponsorship of NSF Geobiology was shown at the beginning and end of the morning and evening podium sessions. The NSF support was also acknowledged on the conference website and at the meeting by the GRC and GRS chairs. The Gordon Research Conferences staff evaluated the attendees’ satisfaction by a thorough questionnaire and the highly positive results were forwarded to the chair and co-chair of the Geobiology GRC and GRS 2020. Both meetings trained junior people in research in geobiology and geochemistry, promoted interest in these fields, supported NSF’s endeavors and developed exposure to — and appreciation for — STEM.
